content.webTitle: He ain't heavy: triathlon star Alistair Brownlee helps sibling Jonny over the line

fields.headline: He ain't heavy: triathlon star Alistair Brownlee helps sibling Jonny over the line
fields.bodyText: At the Rio Olympics they crossed the line together in triumph, winning gold and silver in the triathlon, but on Monday the Brownlee brothers provided a possibly even more enduring image as Alistair, the elder, helped his distressed sibling, Jonny, cross the finishing line. The Brownlees were competing in the final race of triathlon’s World Series in Mexico, where victory in a stiflingly humid Cozumel with their main rival – Spain’s Mario Mola – finishing no higher than fourth, would have made Jonny world champion. That looked on the cards after the brothers had again pushed the pace hard on the swimming and cycling segments until the final stages of the 10km run, which ended the day’s event, when the clear leader started to wobble. Third-placed Alistair, who was out of contention for overall victory himself, spotted his brother weaving across the course before stopping at the side of the road. He put his arm around Jonny and all but carried him for the final few hundred metres, before pushing him across the line for second place. Mola took the title, but the younger Brownlee then had to survive an appeal to disqualify him lodged by the Spanish triathlon federation, which also had an athlete in third spot, for accepting assistance to get over the line. The appeal was dismissed by the International Triathlon Union, citing a rule that states athletes may accept help from fellow competitors, but Jonny still got a ticking off for his pains. “I wish the flipping idiot had just paced it right and won the race,” said Alastair, the two-times Olympic champion. “He could have jogged the last 2km.” Jonny Brownlee required treatment but later, accompanied by a photo of himself lying in a hospital bed on a drip, tweeted that he was OK: “Not the way I wanted to end the season. Thanks @Alibrownleetri, your loyalty is incredible.” Alistair, who also collapsed with exhaustion in Hyde Park in 2010 at the end of a triathlon, said: “If it happened to anyone I would have helped them across the line because it’s an awful position to be in. If he’d conked out before the finish line and there wasn’t medical support it could have been really dangerous. “It was a natural human reaction to my brother but for anyone I would have done the same thing. I think it’s as close to death as you can be in sport.”
